review:
Acorns is an almost flawless investing app, and I would have given it 5 stars if not for a few minor (but rather inconvenient) issues.
First the good:
If you‚Äôre bad at saving money like me, this is the app for you. I have an above average knowledge of stocks and Acorns strategy of investing in diversified indexes is great. The fact that they repeatedly emphasize a buy and hold strategy is great too, and a LOT of my age group in their 20‚Äôs and 30‚Äôs need to hear this. Time in the market >> timing the market, and Acorns takes advantage of this strategy to a T. While the lack of customization for holdings may be a put off to some, most successful investors have portfolios very similar to Acorns. 

Their checking account is a must have for round ups which are so crucial in passive investing. And their debit card feels nice in your hand and is great to use. I only wish it had a touch to pay feature which is very common on new cards

And their customer service is beyond amazing. Prompt with replies and extremely helpful, they really help set this app apart from others.

Now for the bad:
If there‚Äôs any area in which Acorns will lose out to other apps, it‚Äôs the lack of a high yield savings account and saving strategies to keep a more liquid portion of your cash saved for more short term expenses. Take betterment for example, and their savings goals, which allows you to save money for a rainy day AND invest. Apps like So-Fi and Digit have similar strategies. I need to have a separate checking account with savings goals in order to maintain rainy day savings that are kept separate from my spending account, since acorns doesn‚Äôt offer this. 
Im a firm believer that not every dollar you save should be invested, and instead investors need to have a certain amount of money (6-8 months of living expenses) in liquid to tide over rough spells. If this current bear market thought us anything, it‚Äôs the fact that everyone needs a safety buffer. Im surprised Acorns missed this important point. Maybe they overlooked a savings account or maybe they just didn‚Äôt feel the need to offer one.
I just do hope they read this and consider adding one so I can make do with one place to store my money and not have to transfer funds separately into Acorns to spend 

Otherwise this is a brilliant app. Keep up the good work.

review: About seven years ago, I was in the most consistent meditation practice of my life, meditating twice a day every day for 15-30 minutes. Looking back, this practice helped cultivate the most inner peace and stability I‚Äôve ever felt. It is designed to help people who may feel uncomfortable with the idea of mediation, to help those who think they‚Äôre ‚Äúdoing it wrong‚Äù or for those who have trouble sitting still or in silence. I think a lot of people misunderstand the ‚Äúpoint‚Äù of meditation; Headspace does well to illustrate that the point is to slow down an overactive mind so that we can observe, but not attach ourselves to, the deluge of thoughts in order to create inner space so that you can see the world around you more clearly and without judgment. Additionally, Headspace keeps track of the minutes you‚Äôve spent meditating and the daily streak of checking in, which are just little things that help to make us feel good about the time we‚Äôve spent and to make it a little easier to hold ourselves accountable for taking care of ourselves. Whether you are prone to depression or anxiety, have difficulties falling asleep, trouble managing your priorities or letting anger get the best of you, among many other issues people face on a daily basis, there is a mediation (often several!) that, with CONSISTENT practice, will help to minimize those difficulties in daily life. Can‚Äôt recommend highly enough‚Äîworth every cent!

review:
The app and Robinhood as a brokerage are ok, though not great. I use them mostly for the easy access to Bitcoin and Ethereum, but with what was previously Robinhood's greatest benefit (zero commissions) becoming the norm across much of the retail brokerage industry, I seldom use it for much else beyond crypto.

Coming from someone with experience using Interactive Brokers' app and desktop software, ThinkOrSwim, Schwab's app and desktop software, and who has regular access to a Bloomberg terminal, I can tell you the Robinhood app is nothing special. The way orders are entered is probably helpful for newer market participants, but I find it cumbersome and drawn out as someone with more experience (I don't need to go through 2-4 different screens just to say I want a limit buy order for X quantity at Y price!).

Probably my biggest gripe, however, has to do with the price charts. To say they are lacking in quality, detail, and functionality would be an understatement.

Overall, Robinhood is an ok brokerage that makes it very easy to open up an account and start trading or investing, but with the playing field in terms of zero commissions having been leveled and other firms offering much better options in terms of their technology and customer service, I think it's worth your time to look around once you have some experience.

In short, why is the platonic side of this app geared first and foremost with cis-hets in mind, with virtually no liberty for queer people? Do we not deserve friends of our own choosing?
